questions.text: A 34y G3P2 presents to the OPD at 34 weeks. She has had 2 previous lower segment cesarean sections and an ultrasound done at 28 weeks shows an anterior low-lying placenta. She does not complain of bleeding. On examination, the uterus is 32 weeks, cephalic presentation and the FHR is 145 bpm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Order an ultrasound with a Doppler

 

Explanation

 

  • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa
  • The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans 
  • Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes
  • The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient

 

The risk of placenta accreta syndrome (PAS) is highest when both of the following are true:

 

  1. History of â‰¥1 previous cesarean section, AND
  2. Current pregnancy has placenta previa or low-lying placenta

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated

 

Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrreta syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrreta syndromes by doing a Doppler

 

Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The risk of placenta acrreta syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections. 
  • A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accreta syndromes (PAS)

 

Ref: Page 1967, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

Explanation

  • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis
    • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
    • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
    • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
    • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

In Placenta Accrete Syndromes, the abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer

 

Ref: Page no 1974, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: A 34y G2P1 with a previous LSCS presented at 30 weeks with painless vaginal bleeding. The following image was seen on ultrasound doppler. Which of the following is not seen in placenta accreta?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Thickening of the retroplacental myometrium

Explanation

Thinning of the retro-placental myometrium is seen on ultrasound in Placenta Accrete Syndromes (PAS)

Five characteristic sonographic findings suggest Placenta Acceta Syndromes are:

  1. Placental lacunae
  2. Thinning of the retroplacental myometrium
  3. Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface
  4. Bridging vessels from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface
  5. Placental bulge that pushes outward and distorts the contour of the uterus

 

Educational Objective: 

Remember: The investigation of choice to diagnose placenta acrrete syndromes is Ultrasound + Color Doppler

 

Ref: Page 1979, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Match the condition with the time of delivery:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. a-1, b-2, c-2

Explanation

  • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery
  • Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress
  • Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.

 

Educational Objective 

Delivery in different scenarions of APH

  • In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred
  • In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress
  • In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta. 

ERef: Page 1982, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 24y G2P1 with a previous LSCS presented at 28 weeks with painless mild vaginal bleeding. She had a previous similar episode 2 weeks earlier. A scan done was suspicious for placenta accreta and this was confirmed on a Doppler. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Plan an elective classical section at 37 weeks

 

Explanation

 

The mild bleeding encountered is known as warning bleed or sentinel bleed. 

 

  • Management of placenta accreta involves
    • Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks
    • Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta
    • Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ
  • Conservative approaches like leaving the placenta in situ and resection and repair of uterus are less commonly done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & C: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not done for placenta accreta syndromes as the placenta is usually adherent in the lower segment

 

Option D: As the patient is currently stable and bleeding is mild, immediate cesarean is not indicated

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management of placenta accreta involves
    • Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks
    • Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta
    • Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ

 

Page no 1985, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The investigation of choice for placenta accreta is:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Ultrasound with color Doppler

Explanation

  • USG with color Doppler has a high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing placenta accreta syndromes
  • Five characteristic sonographic findings suggest Placenta Acceta Syndromes are:
    • Placental lacunae
    • Thinning of the retroplacental myometrium
    • Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface
    • Bridging vessels from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface
    • Placental bulge that pushes outward and distorts the contour of the uterus

 

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Plain Ultrasound is not as useful as Doppler for diagnosing Placenta accreta
  • Option C: MRI can be added on in doubtful cases especially if the placenta is posteriorly situated
  • Option D: CECT: CT scans are generally contra-indicated in pregnancy and are not useful in diagnosing placenta acrrete syndromes

 

Educational Objective: 

USG with color Doppler has a high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing placenta accreta syndromes and is the investigation of choice

 

Ref: Page no 1980, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Ligation of which of the following vessels in the retroperitoneum will reduce the pulse pressure in a patient who is bleeding during surgery for placenta accreta syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Internal iliac artery

Explanation

  • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes
  • It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation
  • The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus
  • This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.

 

Other Options:

Option A: Uterine artery ligation is the 1st vessel ligated in devascularization surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation

Option C: External iliac artery: Is not ligated as part of devascularization as it does not supply the uterus

Option D: utero-ovarian anastomoses ligation is done as part of devasculariazation surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation

 

Educational Objective: 

  • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes
  • It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation
  • The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus

Ref: Page no 2027, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, G4P3 at 28 weeks of gestation, presents with recurrent episodes of painless vaginal bleeding over the past 1 week. Her medical history is significant for 1 previous cesarean delivery and 1 dilatation and curettage of a previous incomplete abortion. On examination, her vital signs are stable, and the fetal heart rate is reassuring. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a placenta located near the cervix with multiple hypoechoic areas and irregular vascular spaces within the placenta. Laboratory results show an Hb of 8g%. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

  • This is a clinical scenario of placenta accreta syndromes as the history of previous cesarean and D & C with the current ultrasound findings support this diagnosis
  • Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes
    • Stabilization of the patient
    • Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage

Other options

  • Option A: As the patient is stable currently, immediate cesarean is not warranted as she is only 29 weeks
  • Option B: This would have been correct but option D is a better option in the scenario of accreta. If only placenta previa, this would have been the preferred option
  • Option C: There is no role of looking at increasing vascularity on ultrasound and it will not change the management.

Educational Objective:

  • Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes
    • Stabilization of the patient
    • Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage

 

 

Ref: Page 1973, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: What is the best management option for a patient diagnosed with placenta increta at 36 weeks pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Planned elective classical cesarean at 37 weeks followed by hysterectomy

 

Explanation

  • Placenta accrete syndromes includes placenta accreta, placenta increta and placenta percreta
  • As the placenta is adherent to the myometrium, any attempt at separation of the placenta at delivery leads to torrential hemorrhage
  • The best management option thus is to plan an elective cesarean between 34-37 weeks (before the patient goes into labor). Avoid an emergency cesarean unless really required.
  • The cesarean is usually a classical cesarean (upper segment) as the most common site of adherence is in the lower segment (usually at the site of a previous cesarean section)
  • After delivery of the baby, the cord is clamped; no attempt at separation of placenta is done and a hysterectomy is done.
  • Leaving the placenta in situ is not preferred to be done but has been occasionally reported by a few. It may lead to secondary haemorrhage and/ or infection thereby necessitating hysterectomy.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Planned elective classical cesarean at 37 weeks; placenta to be left in situ:
    • Although the 1st part is correct, leaving the placenta in situ isn’t advocated as most studies say that the incidence of secondary hemorrhage/ infection is very high
       
  • Option C: Emergency classical cesarean section now followed by hysterectomy
    • There is no indication for doing an emergency cesarean section. An elective planned cesarean is always preferred in placenta accrete syndromes
       
  • Option D: Emergency classical cesarean section now; placenta to be left in situ
    • There is no indication for an emergency and as mentioned above the placenta should not be left in situ
       

Educational Objective:

  • The best management option for Placenta Accrete Syndromes (PAS) is to plan an elective cesarean between 34-37 weeks (before the patient goes into labor). Avoid an emergency cesarean unless really required.
  • The cesarean is usually a classical cesarean (upper segment) as the most common site of adherence is in the lower segment (usually at the site of a previous cesarean section)
  • After delivery of the baby, the cord is clamped; no attempt at separation of placenta is done and a hysterectomy is done.

 

 

Ref: Page 1984, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
